COC(=O)/C=C/c1ccc(N(C)C(C)=O)nc1 undergo a chemical reaction, leading to the generation of CNc1ccc(/C=C/C(=O)O)cn1 . In this chemical reaction, 50.0 degrees Celsius is commonly regarded as the appropriate temperature. Typically, 4.0 hours is essential for this chemical reaction.

COC(=O)/C=C/c1ccc(N(C)C(C)=O)nc1 undergo a chemical reaction, leading to the generation of CNc1ccc(/C=C/C(=O)O)cn1 . In this chemical reaction, -44.2 degrees Celsius is commonly regarded as the appropriate temperature. Typically, 20.7 hours is essential for this chemical reaction.

COC(=O)/C=C/c1ccc(N(C)C(C)=O)nc1 undergo a chemical reaction, leading to the generation of CNc1ccc(/C=C/C(=O)O)cn1 . In this chemical reaction, 10.6 degrees Celsius is commonly regarded as the appropriate temperature. Typically, 8.0 hours is essential for this chemical reaction.

Write the equations relating $K_{c}$ to $K_{P}$ for each of the following reactions:

(b) $\mathrm{N}_{2} \mathrm{O}_{4}(g) \rightleftharpoons 2 \mathrm{NO}_{2}(g)$

(d) At $227^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$, the following reaction has $K_{c}=0.0952$ :

$$
\mathrm{CH}_{3} \mathrm{OH}(g) \rightleftharpoons \mathrm{CO}(g)+2 \mathrm{H}_{2}(g)
$$

What would be the value of $K_{P}$ at this temperature?
Answer:
(a) $K_{P}=K_{c}(R T)^{-1}$; (b) $K_{P}=K_{c}(R T)$; (c) $K_{P}=K_{c}(R T)$; (d) 160 or $1.6 \times 10^{2}$

1782. Solution - 
The reaction stoichiometry shows that

$$
-\frac{1}{2} \frac{\Delta\left[\mathrm{H}_{2} \mathrm{O}_{2}\right]}{\Delta t}=\frac{1}{2} \frac{\Delta\left[\mathrm{H}_{2} \mathrm{O}\right]}{\Delta t}=\frac{\Delta\left[\mathrm{O}_{2}\right]}{\Delta t}
$$

Therefore:

$$
\frac{1}{2} \times 3.20 \times 10^{-2} \mathrm{~mol} \mathrm{~L}^{-1} \mathrm{~h}^{-1}=\frac{\Delta\left[\mathrm{O}_{2}\right]}{\Delta t}
$$

and

$$
\frac{\Delta\left[\mathrm{O}_{2}\right]}{\Delta t}=1.60 \times 10^{-2} \mathrm{~mol} \mathrm{~L}^{-1} \mathrm{~h}^{-1}
$$

The $-\mathrm{OCH}_{3}$ protons absorb around 3.5 to $4.0 \delta$ because they are on carbon bonded to oxygen. The $\left(\mathrm{CH}_{3}\right)_{3} \mathrm{C}-$ protons absorb near $1.0 \delta$ because they are typical alkane-like protons.

Strategy - 
A two-step reaction has two transition states and an intermediate between them. The $\Delta G^{\ddagger}$ for the overall reaction is the energy change between reactants and the highest-energy transition state-the second one in this case. An exergonic reaction has a negative overall $\Delta G^{\circ}$.

A common experimental approach to the determination of rate laws is the method of initial rates. This method involves measuring reaction rates for multiple experimental trials carried out using different initial reactant concentrations. Comparing the measured rates for these trials permits determination of the reaction orders and, subsequently, the rate constant, which together are used to formulate a rate law. This approach is illustrated in the next two example exercises.

$$

and

question: Could you share some insights into the usual time and temperature prerequisites for this chemical reaction COc1ccc(N)c(C(=O)O)c1.NC(N)=O>O>COc1ccc2[nH]c(=O)[nH]c(=O)c2c1.?
choices: The utilization of COc1ccc(N)c(C(=O)O)c1 and NC(N)=O initiates a reaction resulting in the formation of COc1ccc2[nH]c(=O)[nH]c(=O)c2c1 . Typically, the favored reaction temperature for this chemical reaction is -39.1 degrees Celsius.

The utilization of COc1ccc(N)c(C(=O)O)c1 and NC(N)=O initiates a reaction resulting in the formation of COc1ccc2[nH]c(=O)[nH]c(=O)c2c1 . Typically, the favored reaction temperature for this chemical reaction is 45.5 degrees Celsius.

The utilization of COc1ccc(N)c(C(=O)O)c1 and NC(N)=O initiates a reaction resulting in the formation of COc1ccc2[nH]c(=O)[nH]c(=O)c2c1 . Typically, the favored reaction temperature for this chemical reaction is 27.7 degrees Celsius.

The utilization of COc1ccc(N)c(C(=O)O)c1 and NC(N)=O initiates a reaction resulting in the formation of COc1ccc2[nH]c(=O)[nH]c(=O)c2c1 . Typically, the favored reaction temperature for this chemical reaction is 200.0 degrees Celsius.

1782. Solution - 
The reaction stoichiometry shows that

$$
-\frac{1}{2} \frac{\Delta\left[\mathrm{H}_{2} \mathrm{O}_{2}\right]}{\Delta t}=\frac{1}{2} \frac{\Delta\left[\mathrm{H}_{2} \mathrm{O}\right]}{\Delta t}=\frac{\Delta\left[\mathrm{O}_{2}\right]}{\Delta t}
$$

Therefore:

$$
\frac{1}{2} \times 3.20 \times 10^{-2} \mathrm{~mol} \mathrm{~L}^{-1} \mathrm{~h}^{-1}=\frac{\Delta\left[\mathrm{O}_{2}\right]}{\Delta t}
$$

and

$$
\frac{\Delta\left[\mathrm{O}_{2}\right]}{\Delta t}=1.60 \times 10^{-2} \mathrm{~mol} \mathrm{~L}^{-1} \mathrm{~h}^{-1}
$$

$$

Experiment 2:

$$

$$

$Q_{c}<K_{c}(0.48<0.64)$
The reaction will proceed in the forward direction.

1832. Solution - 
FIGURE 17.10 These two graphs show first- and second-order plots for the dimerization of $\mathrm{C}_{4} \mathrm{H}_{6}$. The linear trend in the second-order plot (right) indicates that the reaction follows second-order kinetics.

According to the second-order integrated rate law, the rate constant is equal to the slope of the $\frac{1}{[A]_{t}}$ versus $t$ plot. Using the data for $t=0 \mathrm{~s}$ and $t=6200 \mathrm{~s}$, the rate constant is estimated as follows:

$$
k=\text { slope }=\frac{\left(481 M^{-1}-100 M^{-1}\right)}{(6200 \mathrm{~s}-0 \mathrm{~s})}=0.0614 \mathrm{M}^{-1} \mathrm{~s}^{-1}
$$

1331. Check Your Learning -

1782. Solution - 
The reaction stoichiometry shows that

$$
-\frac{1}{2} \frac{\Delta\left[\mathrm{H}_{2} \mathrm{O}_{2}\right]}{\Delta t}=\frac{1}{2} \frac{\Delta\left[\mathrm{H}_{2} \mathrm{O}\right]}{\Delta t}=\frac{\Delta\left[\mathrm{O}_{2}\right]}{\Delta t}
$$

Therefore:

$$
\frac{1}{2} \times 3.20 \times 10^{-2} \mathrm{~mol} \mathrm{~L}^{-1} \mathrm{~h}^{-1}=\frac{\Delta\left[\mathrm{O}_{2}\right]}{\Delta t}
$$

and

$$
\frac{\Delta\left[\mathrm{O}_{2}\right]}{\Delta t}=1.60 \times 10^{-2} \mathrm{~mol} \mathrm{~L}^{-1} \mathrm{~h}^{-1}
$$

1778. Solution - 
Considering the stoichiometry of this homogeneous reaction, the rates for the consumption of reactants and formation of products are:

$$
-\frac{1}{4} \frac{\Delta\left[\mathrm{NH}_{3}\right]}{\Delta t}=-\frac{1}{5} \frac{\Delta\left[\mathrm{O}_{2}\right]}{\Delta t}=\frac{1}{4} \frac{\Delta[\mathrm{NO}]}{\Delta t}=\frac{1}{6} \frac{\Delta\left[\mathrm{H}_{2} \mathrm{O}\right]}{\Delta t}
$$

$$

1773. CHAPTER OUTLINE - 1773.3. Chemical Reaction Rates
$$
\frac{-\Delta\left[\mathrm{H}_{2} \mathrm{O}_{2}\right]}{\Delta t}=\frac{-(0.500 \mathrm{~mol} / \mathrm{L}-1.000 \mathrm{~mol} / \mathrm{L})}{(6.00 \mathrm{~h}-0.00 \mathrm{~h})}=0.0833 \mathrm{~mol} \mathrm{~L}^{-1} \mathrm{~h}^{-1}
$$

Notice that the reaction rates vary with time, decreasing as the reaction proceeds. Results for the last 6-hour period yield a reaction rate of:

$$
\frac{-\Delta\left[\mathrm{H}_{2} \mathrm{O}_{2}\right]}{\Delta t}=\frac{-(0.0625 \mathrm{~mol} / \mathrm{L}-0.125 \mathrm{~mol} / \mathrm{L})}{(24.00 \mathrm{~h}-18.00 \mathrm{~h})}=0.010 \mathrm{~mol} \mathrm{~L}^{-1} \mathrm{~h}^{-1}
$$

Show that the data in Figure 17.2 can be represented by a first-order rate law by graphing $\ln \left[\mathrm{H}_{2} \mathrm{O}_{2}\right]$ versus time. Determine the rate constant for the decomposition of $\mathrm{H}_{2} \mathrm{O}_{2}$ from these data.

1863. Relating Reaction Mechanisms to Rate Laws - 
This expression may be rearranged to express the concentration of the intermediate in terms of the reactant NO:

$$
\left(\frac{\mathrm{k}_{1}[\mathrm{NO}]^{2}}{\mathrm{k}_{-1}}\right)=\left[\mathrm{N}_{2} \mathrm{O}_{2}\right]
$$

Since intermediate species concentrations are not used in formulating rate laws for overall reactions, this approach is sometimes necessary, as illustrated in the following example exercise.

$$

Answer:
Spontaneous; $n=2 ; E_{\text {cell }}^{\circ}=+0.291 \mathrm{~V} ; \Delta G^{\circ}=-56.2 \frac{\mathrm{~kJ}}{\mathrm{~mol}} ; K=6.8 \times 10^{9}$.

696. Answer: - 
Yes, a single-replacement reaction. $\mathrm{Sn}(s)$ is the reductant, $\mathrm{HCl}(g)$ is the oxidant.

Strategy - 
When solving a problem that asks you to predict a reaction product, begin by looking at the functional group(s) in the reactants and deciding what kind of reaction is likely to occur. In the present instance, the reactant is an alkene that will probably undergo an electrophilic addition reaction with HCl . Next, recall what you know about electrophilic addition reactions to predict the product. You know that electrophilic addition reactions follow Markovnikov's rule, so $\mathrm{H}^{+}$will add to the double-bond carbon that has one alkyl group ( C 2 on the ring) and the Cl will add to the double-bond carbon that has two alkyl groups ( C 1 on the ring).

Solution - 13.12 DEPT ${ }^{13} \mathrm{C}$ NMR Spectroscopy
Putting together the information from all three spectra makes it possible to tell the number of hydrogens attached to each carbon. The CH carbons are identified in the DEPT- 90 spectrum, the $\mathrm{CH}_{2}$ carbons are identified as negative peaks in the DEPT- 135 spectrum, the $\mathrm{CH}_{3}$ carbons are identified by subtracting the CH peaks from the positive peaks in the DEPT-135 spectrum, and quaternary carbons are identified by subtracting all peaks in the DEPT-135 spectrum from the peaks in the broadband-decoupled spectrum.

c Subtract DEPT-135 from broadband-decoupled spectrum

Strategy - 
When solving a problem that asks you to predict a reaction product, begin by looking at the functional group(s) in the reactants and deciding what kind of reaction is likely to occur. In the present instance, the reactant is an alkene that will probably undergo an electrophilic addition reaction with HCl . Next, recall what you know about electrophilic addition reactions to predict the product. You know that electrophilic addition reactions follow Markovnikov's rule, so $\mathrm{H}^{+}$will add to the double-bond carbon that has one alkyl group ( C 2 on the ring) and the Cl will add to the double-bond carbon that has two alkyl groups ( C 1 on the ring).

Solution - 6.11 A Comparison Between Biological Reactions and Laboratory Reactions
TABLE 6.4 A Comparison of Typical Laboratory and Biological Reactions A Comparison of Typical Laboratory and Biological Reactions

|  | Laboratory reaction | Biological reaction |
| :--- | :--- | :--- |
| Solvent | Organic liquid, such as ether | Aqueous environment in cells |
| Temperature | Wide range; -80 to $150^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$ | Temperature of organism |
| Catalyst | Either none, or very simple | Large, complex enzymes needed |
| Reagent size | Usually small and simple | Relatively complex coenzymes |
| Specificity | Little specificity for substrate | Very high specificity for substrate |

question: Could you share some insights into the usual time and temperature prerequisites for this chemical reaction CN(N)C(=O)OC(C)(C)C.N#Cc1ccc(F)c(B(O)O)c1.CCN(CC)CC>ClCCCl.CC(=O)[O-].[Cu+2].CC(=O)[O-]>CN(Nc1cc(C#N)ccc1F)C(=O)OC(C)(C)C.?
choices: CN(Nc1cc(C#N)ccc1F)C(=O)OC(C)(C)C  are generated as a result of the chemical interaction between CN(N)C(=O)OC(C)(C)C and N#Cc1ccc(F)c(B(O)O)c1. Typically, -83.2 degrees Celsius is the temperature at which this chemical reaction is most efficient.

CN(Nc1cc(C#N)ccc1F)C(=O)OC(C)(C)C  are generated as a result of the chemical interaction between CN(N)C(=O)OC(C)(C)C and N#Cc1ccc(F)c(B(O)O)c1. Typically, 88.9 degrees Celsius is the temperature at which this chemical reaction is most efficient.

CN(Nc1cc(C#N)ccc1F)C(=O)OC(C)(C)C  are generated as a result of the chemical interaction between CN(N)C(=O)OC(C)(C)C and N#Cc1ccc(F)c(B(O)O)c1. Typically, 33.0 degrees Celsius is the temperature at which this chemical reaction is most efficient.

CN(Nc1cc(C#N)ccc1F)C(=O)OC(C)(C)C  are generated as a result of the chemical interaction between CN(N)C(=O)OC(C)(C)C and N#Cc1ccc(F)c(B(O)O)c1. Typically, 60.0 degrees Celsius is the temperature at which this chemical reaction is most efficient.

choices: Cc1ccnc(-c2nc3cc(F)cc(F)c3c(Nc3cncc(-c4ccnc(N)n4)c3)c2C)c1  are synthesized through the chemical interaction between Cc1ccnc(-c2nc3cc(F)cc(F)c3c(Nc3cncc(B(O)O)c3)c2C)c1 and Nc1nccc(Cl)n1. Generally, -15.6 degrees Celsius is considered the ideal reaction temperature for this chemical process. Typically, 5.5 hours is needed for this chemical reaction to take place.

Generally, 61.5 degrees Celsius is considered the ideal reaction temperature for this chemical process. Typically, 11.3 hours is needed for this chemical reaction to take place.

Cc1ccnc(-c2nc3cc(F)cc(F)c3c(Nc3cncc(-c4ccnc(N)n4)c3)c2C)c1  are synthesized through the chemical interaction between Cc1ccnc(-c2nc3cc(F)cc(F)c3c(Nc3cncc(B(O)O)c3)c2C)c1 and Nc1nccc(Cl)n1. This expression may be rearranged to express the concentration of the intermediate in terms of the reactant NO:

$$
\left(\frac{\mathrm{k}_{1}[\mathrm{NO}]^{2}}{\mathrm{k}_{-1}}\right)=\left[\mathrm{N}_{2} \mathrm{O}_{2}\right]
$$

Since intermediate species concentrations are not used in formulating rate laws for overall reactions, this approach is sometimes necessary, as illustrated in the following example exercise.

1801. Answer: - 
order in $\mathrm{CH}_{3} \mathrm{OH}=1$; order in $\mathrm{CH}_{3} \mathrm{CH}_{2} \mathrm{OCOCH}_{3}=0$; overall order $=1$

A common experimental approach to the determination of rate laws is the method of initial rates. This method involves measuring reaction rates for multiple experimental trials carried out using different initial reactant concentrations. Comparing the measured rates for these trials permits determination of the reaction orders and, subsequently, the rate constant, which together are used to formulate a rate law. This approach is illustrated in the next two example exercises.

TABLE 18.2 shows some of the many different kinds of carbonyl compounds. All contain an acyl group ( $\mathrm{R}-\mathrm{C}=\mathrm{O}$ ) bonded to another substituent. The R part of the acyl group can be practically any organic part/ structure, and the other substituent to which the acyl group is bonded might be a carbon, hydrogen, oxygen, halogen, nitrogen, or sulfur.

| Ketone | <smiles>[R]C([R])=O</smiles> | -one |
| Carboxylic acid | <smiles>[R]C(=O)O</smiles> | -oic acid |
| Acid halide | <smiles>[R]C([X])=O</smiles> | -yl or -oyl halide |
| Acid anhydride | <smiles>[R]C([R])=O</smiles> | -oic anhydride |
| Acyl phosphate | <smiles>[R]C(=O)OP(=O)([O-])[O-]</smiles> | -yl phosphate |

Solution - 25.6 Reactions of Monosaccharides
Because monosaccharides have only two kinds of functional groups, hydroxyls and carbonyls, most of the chemistry of monosaccharides is the familiar chemistry of these two groups. As we've seen, alcohols can be converted into esters and ethers and can be oxidized; carbonyl compounds can react with nucleophiles and can be reduced.

A common experimental approach to the determination of rate laws is the method of initial rates. This method involves measuring reaction rates for multiple experimental trials carried out using different initial reactant concentrations. Comparing the measured rates for these trials permits determination of the reaction orders and, subsequently, the rate constant, which together are used to formulate a rate law. This approach is illustrated in the next two example exercises.

1367. Solution - 
As for all equilibrium calculations in this text, use the simplified equations for $Q$ and $K$ and disregard any concentration or pressure units, as noted previously in this section.
(a) Before any product is formed, $\left[\mathrm{NO}_{2}\right]=\frac{0.10 \mathrm{~mol}}{1.0 \mathrm{~L}}=0.10 M$, and $\left[\mathrm{N}_{2} \mathrm{O}_{4}\right]=0 \mathrm{M}$. Thus,

$$
Q_{c}=\frac{\left[\mathrm{N}_{2} \mathrm{O}_{4}\right]}{\left[\mathrm{NO}_{2}\right]^{2}}=\frac{0}{0.10^{2}}=0
$$

(b) At equilibrium, $K_{c}=Q_{c}=\frac{\left[\mathrm{N}_{2} \mathrm{O}_{4}\right]}{\left[\mathrm{NO}_{2}\right]^{2}}=\frac{0.042}{0.016^{2}}=1.6 \times 10^{2}$. The equilibrium constant is $1.6 \times 10^{2}$.

The rate constant for the first-order decomposition of cyclobutane, $\mathrm{C}_{4} \mathrm{H}_{8}$ at $500^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$ is $9.2 \times 10^{-3} \mathrm{~s}^{-1}$ :

question: I'd like to know more about the usual duration and temperature prerequisites for this chemical reaction CCOC(=O)[C@@H](NC(=O)OCc1ccccc1)[C@@H](C)C(F)(F)F.[OH-].[Na+]>C1CCOC1.CO.O>C[C@H]([C@H](NC(=O)OCc1ccccc1)C(=O)O)C(F)(F)F.. Could you offer some clarification?
choices: CCOC(=O)[C@@H](NC(=O)OCc1ccccc1)[C@@H](C)C(F)(F)F undergo chemical changes, resulting in the formation of C[C@H]([C@H](NC(=O)OCc1ccccc1)C(=O)O)C(F)(F)F . A period of 24.0 hours is typically consumed in this chemical reaction. In this chemical reaction, the preferred temperature typically falls around 99.7 degrees Celsius.

CCOC(=O)[C@@H](NC(=O)OCc1ccccc1)[C@@H](C)C(F)(F)F undergo chemical changes, resulting in the formation of C[C@H]([C@H](NC(=O)OCc1ccccc1)C(=O)O)C(F)(F)F . A period of 10.7 hours is typically consumed in this chemical reaction. In this chemical reaction, the preferred temperature typically falls around 96.8 degrees Celsius.

CCOC(=O)[C@@H](NC(=O)OCc1ccccc1)[C@@H](C)C(F)(F)F undergo chemical changes, resulting in the formation of C[C@H]([C@H](NC(=O)OCc1ccccc1)C(=O)O)C(F)(F)F . A period of 1.0 hours is typically consumed in this chemical reaction. In this chemical reaction, the preferred temperature typically falls around 25.0 degrees Celsius.

CCOC(=O)[C@@H](NC(=O)OCc1ccccc1)[C@@H](C)C(F)(F)F undergo chemical changes, resulting in the formation of C[C@H]([C@H](NC(=O)OCc1ccccc1)C(=O)O)C(F)(F)F . A period of 6.8 hours is typically consumed in this chemical reaction. In this chemical reaction, the preferred temperature typically falls around -66.4 degrees Celsius.

question: Can you provide insight into the standard time periods and thermal conditions required for this chemical reaction NC1CCCCC1.CCOC(=O)CN(CP(=O)(OCl)OCl)C(=O)C(F)(F)F>CCOCC>CCOC(=O)CN(CP(=O)(ONC1CCCCC1)ONC1CCCCC1)C(=O)C(F)(F)F. to proceed optimally?
choices: The synthesis of CCOC(=O)CN(CP(=O)(ONC1CCCCC1)ONC1CCCCC1)C(=O)C(F)(F)F  is initiated by the chemical reaction of CCOC(=O)CN(CP(=O)(OCl)OCl)C(=O)C(F)(F)F and NC1CCCCC1. This chemical reaction typically involves a time span of 8.0 hours. Generally, 25.0 degrees Celsius is acknowledged as the standard temperature for this reaction.

The synthesis of CCOC(=O)CN(CP(=O)(ONC1CCCCC1)ONC1CCCCC1)C(=O)C(F)(F)F  is initiated by the chemical reaction of CCOC(=O)CN(CP(=O)(OCl)OCl)C(=O)C(F)(F)F and NC1CCCCC1. This chemical reaction typically involves a time span of 20.3 hours. Generally, -86.0 degrees Celsius is acknowledged as the standard temperature for this reaction.

The synthesis of CCOC(=O)CN(CP(=O)(ONC1CCCCC1)ONC1CCCCC1)C(=O)C(F)(F)F  is initiated by the chemical reaction of CCOC(=O)CN(CP(=O)(OCl)OCl)C(=O)C(F)(F)F and NC1CCCCC1. This chemical reaction typically involves a time span of 14.2 hours. Generally, -11.4 degrees Celsius is acknowledged as the standard temperature for this reaction.

The synthesis of CCOC(=O)CN(CP(=O)(ONC1CCCCC1)ONC1CCCCC1)C(=O)C(F)(F)F  is initiated by the chemical reaction of CCOC(=O)CN(CP(=O)(OCl)OCl)C(=O)C(F)(F)F and NC1CCCCC1. WORKED EXAMPLE 11.4 - 
Predicting the Double-Bond Stereochemistry of the Product in an E2 Reaction
What stereochemistry do you expect for the alkene obtained by E2 elimination of (1S,2S)-1,2-dibromo-1,2-diphenylethane?

Solution - 
The $-\mathrm{OCH}_{3}$ protons absorb around 3.5 to $4.0 \delta$ because they are on carbon bonded to oxygen. The $\left(\mathrm{CH}_{3}\right)_{3} \mathrm{C}-$ protons absorb near $1.0 \delta$ because they are typical alkane-like protons.
